sn35.53:1: At Sāvatthī. Then a certain bhikkhu approached the Blessed One, paid homage to him, sat down to one side,sn.iv.3and said to him:
sn35.53:2: "Bhikkhu, when one knows and sees the eye as impermanent, ignorance is abandoned and true knowledge arises.[n.1]Spk: It is also abandoned for one who knows and sees by way of suffering and nonself, but impermanence is stated out of consideration for the inclination of the person being instructed.When one knows and sees forms as impermanent … When one knows and sees as impermanent whatever feeling arises with mind-contact as condition—whether pleasant or painful or neither-painful-norpleasant—ignorance is abandoned and true knowledge arises. When one knows and sees thus, bhikkhu, ignorance is abandoned and true knowledge arises."
